title: Wall Street's private equity hangover
text:
One event to start: We've confirmed our latest panel for Due Diligence Live on October 12 in London. Join the DD team as we host a discussion about shifting investor attitudes to ESG. DD Live will gather the biggest names in global finance. To gain early-bird access to the event and find more details go here.

In today's newsletter:

  • LBO financing hits the skids

  • The battle inside the Kuwait Investment Authority 

  • Venture capital's silent crash 

Banks that gorged on the LBO gravy train eat losses

Investment banks such as Goldman Sachs, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase had a good thing going during a decade-long surge in private equity takeovers.

The Wall Street trio financed an ever-rising tide of large leveraged buyouts without suffering significant losses as cash poured into the buyout industry and an era of low interest rates had debt investors begging for a piece of the action.

But that was before the war in Ukraine.

Surging inflation and interest rates have made it harder to sell the debt that backs LBOs that were agreed in better times. That has left tens of billions of dollars worth of takeover debt stuck on banks' balance sheets, the FT's Eric Platt and DD's Antoine Gara report.

The hangover has ground the bank financing market to a halt.

“The traditional bank-financing and high-yield markets are effectively shut at the moment,” Kewsong Lee, chief executive of Carlyle Group, told the FT.

JPMorgan chief executive Jamie Dimon estimated in July that banks are on the hook for less than $100bn of financing packages, roughly a fifth of the level seen in 2007 on the precipice of the financial crisis.

It's a scenario leveraged finance bankers could've hardly imagined just a few months ago, as they finalised debt packages for private equity megadeals including a $14bn buyout of McAfee and a $17bn takeover of Athenahealth. (Not to mention a $44bn surprise from Elon Musk that was just around the corner.)

A nightmare has played out instead.

A group of lenders, including Goldman, BofA and Credit Suisse, financing Vista Equity and Elliott Management's $16.5bn takeover of software company Citrix could lose $1bn or more on the deal, according to people involved in the transaction.

The Citrix deal, as well as a $5.4bn financing package for Apollo's takeover of automotive supplier Tenneco, was postponed until after Labor Day.

Lenders are hoping to avoid the fate of a Goldman-led group's financing of Clayton, Dubilier & Rice's £10bn takeover of UK grocer Wm Morrison. The deal led to £200mn in gross losses, the FT reported last week. Catch up on the DD take, if you missed it.

Bankers have been sidelined as their bloated balance sheets make it difficult to assemble new financings, leaving private equity dealmakers to turn to direct lenders instead.

Hellman & Friedman and Permira's $10.2bn takeover of software firm Zendesk is being financed with over $4bn in private debt raised by a consortium of non-bank lenders led by Blackstone Credit.

Those involved in the deal say it would be hard to replicate such a large financing now as souring markets cause direct lenders to trim exposures and become more selective.

“People are still launching new processes,” said one person. “I'm not exactly sure why, to be honest with you.”

Senior dealmakers, meanwhile, have little sympathy for the banks. As one noted to DD, buyouts generated strong underwriting fees for a decade. Everyone has to eat a deal every once in a while.

Inside the clash at one of the Gulf's most powerful funds

It's a bit of a mess inside the Kuwait Investment Authority at the moment.

For decades, the emirate's $700bn-plus sovereign wealth fund garnered a reputation as a powerful and respected investor, while keeping a low profile.

Then, the KIA abruptly sacked Saleh al-Ateeqi, the head of its London investment arm, the Kuwait Investment Office, dragging it into the spotlight.

Founded in 1953, the KIA is the guardian of Kuwait's wealth for a post-oil future. But the departure of Ateeqi has exposed the rising tensions within the fund between those who want to modernise, and an entrenched old guard opposed to change, the FT reports.

It has not explained its decision to fire Ateeqi, which capped a four-year period in which the KIO became embroiled in a string of legal battles with former staff, internal investigations and rising tensions between the London office and leadership in Kuwait.

Ateeqi's backers said his firing was politically motivated, blaming a power struggle between those attempting to reform the fund and an old guard at the KIA. Ateeqi is now suing Kuwait's finance minister and the managing director of the KIA who fired him.  

With various factions pitted against each other, one fund manager who invests on behalf of the KIA told the FT: “It's chaos there now.”

The venture party goes kaput

The lure of astronomical returns led Silicon Valley outsiders to embrace venture capital.

But plummeting valuations have now left many with regrets. Not that they're keen to admit it.

Venture capital is on a crash course with reality, the FT's Richard Waters writes in an FT Big Read, as “crossover” investors who've shifted billions from public markets into the VC world reassess their bets.

With no daily market indices to shed light on how bad it really is, investors and entrepreneurs feeling the pain have been allowed to do so in relative privacy.

It's mostly when companies try to raise cash that they have to face reality, often in the public eye.

Nearly half a trillion dollars has been wiped from the valuation of once high-flying fintechs since the start of 2020. Swedish buy now, pay later group Klarna sent shockwaves through the industry when it raised money at a $5.7bn valuation — 87 per cent less than its venture capital backers judged it was worth a year ago.

How is the industry responding? “We're probably somewhere between anger and bargaining,” in the five stages of grief, says Josh Wolfe, co-founder of Lux Capital.

Perhaps the most optimistic take, in a world dominated by optimists, is that the crunch will leave good start-ups — with real products and some financial discipline — with less competition as the excesses fade away.

Job moves

  • Arm, the UK semiconductor designer backed by SoftBank, has appointed SoftBank Investment Advisers' general counsel Spencer Collins as chief legal officer.

  • Instagram head Adam Mosseri is moving to London, signalling a strategic shift for the social networking app that is in a fierce battle with viral video platform TikTok to attract and retain younger audiences.

  • Barclays has appointed senior UBS M&A banker Adrian Beidas as co-head of its UK advisory business.

  • Deutsche Bank credit trader Matthew Mezger has left the lender after 16 years to join cryptocurrency trading firm Digital Currency Group.

  • Standard Chartered has appointed former Standard Life chief financial officer Jackie Hunt as an independent non-executive director.

  • Centerview Partners dealmakers David Handler and David Neequaye are leaving to launch a boutique M&A advisory firm, per The Wall Street Journal.

  • Skadden has hired Allen & Overy partner Kate Davies to join its disputes and arbitration practice in London.

  • Goodwin has hired Winfried Carli, a leveraged finance partner from rival Shearman & Sterling, to join its private equity practice in Munich.

Smart reads

Money trail “Don't eff this up rafiq,” private equity tycoon Arif Naqvi wrote in an email. Pakistan forbids foreign nationals and companies from funding political parties, but these groups sent millions to a company owned by Naqvi which passed money on to Imran Khan's party, writes Simon Clark for the FT. 

A handout for billionaires Private equity lobbyists' attempts to justify the carried interest tax break are mostly baloney. If abolishing the perk meant breaking Wall Street's spell over Washington, it would be welcome, writes the FT's Mark Vandevelde.

Perks of the job Elite law firm Kirkland & Ellis's backing of its private equity clients extends beyond advice. Its partners have invested in various internal funds that buy into private equity funds, which in some cases invest in the deals they'd worked on, Bloomberg reports.

News round-up

Saudi Aramco to buy Valvoline's products arm for $2.65bn (FT)

Deutsche Bank broke its own rules in enabling tax fraud, internal probe finds (FT + Lex)

Wall Street watchdog charges 11 in ‘massive' crypto Ponzi scheme (FT)

German regulator says Adler overstated 2019 accounts by up to €233mn (FT)

Permira buys stake in distressed debt content provider Reorg (FT)

LeBron James invests in Canyon as global bicycle boom continues (FT)

Christian Candy sells ‘Candyland' estate for £125mn (FT)

HSBC pledges to restore dividend to pre-pandemic levels (FT)

Alibaba to ‘strive' to keep New York listing despite addition to SEC watchlist (FT)
